channel.title: Does it work?
channel.description:
Well while sitting in biology, bored shitless because i hate biology class... i suddenly had a thought: What if you put two mirror opposite to each other both exactly parallel to each other, and then shined some sort of light source at one mirror and then took the light source out..... would the light just keep hitting each mirror and bouncing back to the other?
e.g.: | | | | | <-------light | | | | | mirror mirror 2
| | | | | <-------------------> | | | | | mirror mirror 2
ideas? philosophy? post away...

item.title: Does it work?
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:27, topic:154057”][quote author=BobDole81 link=topic=210458.msg1844294#msg1844294 date=1193367713]
Not at all. Perpetual motion implies that perfectly efficient work is being done by some force and that energy is being “consumed”. In our light example, there is no work being done since light is pure energy (has no “mass”, though this one can be argued). Light does go on forever if there is nothing in its path. Thus, perpetual motion does not apply.
[/quote]

Well perpetual motion assumes ideal situations. It isn’t necessarily accelerating, so no force is required to keep it moving. In the real world, there’s gravity and intermolecular forces. Same with the light example. In theory it is possible for light to bounce infinitely many times between mirrors. In actuality, mirrors are never perfect, dust particles deflect light rays, air itself bends light rays. So I agree with Exception in saying this is similar to a perpetual motion machine.[/quote]

I’ll give you that I was thinking more along the lines of a perpetual mechanical motion, which does indeed violate the laws of physics. While large gravitational forces can indeed affect the path traveled by light (in flat 3-space only though…if you consider the universe as curved four-space, the light actually travels in a straight path…its just the spacial “medium” which is curved), light does not slow down because of this. But prorogation through different materials does indeed altar the speed of light.

However, consider the scenario where light (preferably low-frequency) is traveling in free space and there is nothing in its path. Would it not continue moving on forever? Thus would this not also be perpetual motion? Note, this is not necessarily an ideal scenario since you are maintaining the properties of the universe but are simply giving it a clear path - it is hypothetical though, obviously.

item.dc:creator: @XxKanexX Kane.
item.description:
@XxKanexX wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:5, topic:154057”]Supposing you had 2 perfectly smooth and perfectly reflective mirrors, I don’t see why it wouldn’t if you aligned it properly (this would have to be such an idea scenario that I’m ignoring the difficulties of aligning the light beam perfectly). Discounting quantum effects (like photon-photon interaction), a single photon could bounce back and forth for all eternity for all anyone cares. Note that you would not be able to see the light at all…if all the light is trapped bouncing back and forth, none would approach your eye and so you could not see it.

Anyway, Light does not simply dim over time. In terms of relativity, light moves through space at the speed of light (obviously), but thus moves through time at a speed of 0. Light does not age at all. If you’re referring to a Doppler shift, I don’t believe it would really apply here since the system is at rest. But even a Doppler shift is just an illusion of loss/gain of energy. Light does not “lose” energy unless it interacts with particles.[/quote]

item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Supposing you had 2 perfectly smooth and perfectly reflective mirrors, I don’t see why it wouldn’t if you aligned it properly (this would have to be such an ideal scenario that I’m ignoring the difficulties of aligning the light beam perfectly). Discounting quantum effects (like photon-photon interaction), a single photon could bounce back and forth for all eternity for all anyone cares. Note that you would not be able to see the light at all…if all the light is trapped bouncing back and forth, none would approach your eye and so you could not see light coming from that area.

Anyway, Light does not simply dim over time. In terms of relativity, light moves through space at the speed of light (obviously), but thus moves through time at a speed of 0. Light does not age at all. If you’re referring to a Doppler shift, I don’t believe it would really apply here since the system is at rest. But even a Doppler shift is just an illusion of loss/gain of energy. Light does not “lose” energy unless it interacts with particles.
